1.text: “Indeed, my eyes have seen all this; my ears have heard and understood.

2.text: What you know, I also know; I am not inferior to you.

3.text: Yet I desire to speak to the Almighty and argue my case before God.

4.text: You, however, smear with lies; you are all worthless physicians.

5.text: If only you would remain silent; for that would be your wisdom!

6.text: Hear now my argument, and listen to the plea of my lips.

7.text: Will you speak wickedly on God’s behalf or speak deceitfully for Him?

8.text: Would you show Him partiality or argue in His defense?

9.text: Would it be well when He examined you? Could you deceive Him as you would deceive a man?

10.text: Surely He would rebuke you if you secretly showed partiality.

11.text: Would His majesty not terrify you? Would the dread of Him not fall upon you?

12.text: Your maxims are proverbs of ashes; your defenses are defenses of clay.

13.text: Be silent, and I will speak. Then let come to me what may.

14.text: Why do I put myself at risk and take my life in my own hands?

15.text: Though He slay me, I will hope in Him. I will still defend my ways to His face.

16.text: Moreover, this will be my salvation, for no godless man can appear before Him.

17.text: Listen carefully to my words; let my declaration ring in your ears.

18.text: See now, I have prepared my case; I know that I will be vindicated.

19.text: Can anyone indict me? If so, I will be silent and die.

20.text: Only grant these two things to me, so that I need not hide from You:

21.text: Withdraw Your hand from me, and do not let Your terror frighten me.

22.text: Then call me, and I will answer, or let me speak, and You can reply.

23.text: How many are my iniquities and sins? Reveal to me my transgression and sin.

24.text: Why do You hide Your face and consider me as Your enemy?

25.text: Would You frighten a windblown leaf? Would You chase after dry chaff?

26.text: For You record bitter accusations against me and bequeath to me the iniquities of my youth.

27.text: You put my feet in the stocks and stand watch over all my paths; You set a limit for the soles of my feet.

28.text: So man wastes away like something rotten, like a moth-eaten garment.
